Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, interactions between ultracold Rydberg atoms will be explored. Ultracold rubidium atoms, at temperatures less than one thousandth of a degree above absolute zero, will be prepared using laser cooling techniques. These atoms will then be transferred to highly-excited Rydberg states with lasers. Such states are unusual in that the electron lives very far from the nucleus, making them very fragile and easily perturbed by other atoms, even when the atoms are far apart. Various manifestations of these strong interactions between Rydberg atoms will be investigated. Specifically, the formation of very large molecules comprised of Rydberg atoms will be explored. Also, novel ion-pair states, where one atom steals the electron from its partner, will be probed. Finally, various exchange processes, where the interacting atoms trade their states of excitation, will be studied.

In performing this research, students and postdocs will receive valuable professional training in laser-based atomic and molecular physics, ultimately enhancing the high-tech workforce. Results of the research will be disseminated through journal publications and conference presentations, thereby informing the scientific community of our findings. Regarding scientific impact, very large Rydberg molecules are an exotic form of matter, exhibiting novel types of binding. Also, interactions between Rydberg atoms are the key mechanism in a number of possible schemes for quantum information processing. Finally, ultracold Rydberg atoms are closely related to cold plasmas, which have been used to form cold antihydrogen atoms in Rydberg states.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated ultracold rubidium atoms in Rydberg states. These are states where the valence electron is highly excited and thus barely bound. Part of the effort was devoted to properties of isolated atoms, while other experiments examined interactions between atoms in Rydberg states. Laser cooling of the atoms to very low temperatures resulted in greatly reduced Doppler shifts and small energy spreads, allowing more precise measurements and improved control of atomic interactions. Interactions between Rydberg atoms are of interest due to their potential applications in quantum computing.

In isolated atoms, laser spectroscopy was performed on nominally forbidden, and therefore very weak, transitions to certain Rydberg states in order to determine just how weak these transitions are. Also, a nominally forbidden transition between two excited states was examined in detail in order to determine the relative contributions of two distinct types of forbidden transitions, magnetic dipole and electric quadrupole. The results of these experiments provide valuable tests of sophisticated quantum theories of the structure of many-electron atoms.

In the interaction experiments, we started by forming ultracold diatomic molecules by binding together two ultracold atoms by laser excitation, a process known as photoassociation. These molecules were then excited to unusual states in which the two atoms spend most of their time quite far apart. In one set of experiments, ion-pair states were investigated. In such states, the two atoms do not equally share the valence electrons responsible for the binding. One of the electrons is transferred to the other atom, so the molecule is effectively a positive ion and a negative ion, bound together by the Coulomb interaction. When the two atoms are far apart, this system resembles a Rydberg atom where the highly-excited electron, loosely-bound to the positive ion, has been replaced by a negative ion, yielding a so-called heavy Rydberg atom. Molecular states with some degree of ion-pair character were explored by mapping out the energies associated with their vibrational motion. Molecular ion-pair states are of interest because they probe the coupling between covalent states, when the atoms are close together, and ionic states, when the atoms are far apart. Also, they may provide a route for forming unusual low-temperature plasmas consisting of positive and negative ions.

In another set of experiments, we explored unconventional molecular states in which one atom is excited to a Rydberg state, and a second atom in its ground state is bound within the Rydberg wave function. Here the binding is provided by the scattering of the almost-free Rydberg electron from the ground-state atom. This novel type of chemical bond, where the binding energy oscillates with the separation between the atoms, is an example of the new phenomena at the intersection of physics and chemistry that can be explored at ultralow temperatures.
